titlestmt.titleproper: Finding aid to the Anne MacKay papers SSC.MS.00472
titlestmt.author: Sylvia Hickman, Madison White, and Madeline Michels

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-06-07 14:26:38 -0400.

change.item: This record was migrated from InMagic DB Textworks to ArchivesSpace.
Updated legacy finding aid and added some further notes.
Updated with new arrangement and added container inventory

did.abstract: The collection contains personal and business files of Anne Mackay, an amatuer theatre director, playwright, and author, who was prominent in the New York lesbian community in the 20th century. It includes materials regarding MacKay's amateur theater work, as well as her work as an author of fiction, nonfiction and poetry. Also well-documented is her active participation in reunion activities at her alma mater Vassar College (Class of 1949).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for use without restriction beyond the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The collection was gifted by Anne MacKay between 1998 to 2012.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is divided into five series.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Anne MacKay was an amatuer theatre director, playwrite, and author, who was prominent in the lesbian community of New York in the 20th century. She was born in New York, NY on March 31, 1928 to Franklin MacKay and Isabel (Dorman) MacKay. She grew up in New York City, Corning, and Orient, NY; Pittsfield, MA; and Berkeley, CA. Summers were spent with extended family in Orient, NY, on the North Fork of Long Island. MacKay attended the Dalton School in New York, and graduated from Vassar College in 1949. From 1949 to 1953, she was stage manager for various New York theater companies, and from 1953 to 1973 she taught Drama at the Dalton School. She was employed as Director of Theatre Arts at the Horace Mann School in New York from 1973 to 1991, when she retired.

MacKay was active in the amateur theater scene, creating and directing three lesbian musical revues, including "Taking Liberties," performed at Symphony Space in New York in 1984. She also wrote poetry and several books about lesbianism and other topics, including Wolf Girls of Vassar on the experience of lesbian students at Vassar. MacKay was active in the Vassar Alumnae community, and founded the Lesbian and Gay Alumnae of Vassar College. She was also a member of a lesbian community on Long Island's North Fork and a founder of that group's women's health initiative, the North Fork Women for Women Fund, for which she also served as archivist. She died in 2012.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Anne MacKay papers, Sophia Smith Collection, SSC-MS-00472, Smith College Special Collections, Northampton, Mass.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The collection arrived at the Sophia Smith Collection in four batches, and had no discernable order. In 2019, Madison White, Sylvia Hickman, and 3 student workers, Catherine Zeng, Ellen Brancart, and Madeline Michels, processed the collection into one coherent structure. Papers were moved into archival folders (keeping original folder titles when possible) and arranged into series. A container list was made and the finding aid was updated.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: North Fork Women for Women Fund Records, Voices of Feminism Oral History Project

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains the personal and professional papers of Anne MacKay, reflecting MacKay's decades of teaching theater at two prestigious NYC prep schools (Dalton and Horace Mann Schools) and her amateur theater work. The collection also includes her work as an author of both fiction, nonfiction and poetry. Particularly well documented is her active participation in reunion activities at her alma mater Vassar College (Class of 1949). Materials include books she wrote or edited, literary manuscript, scripts, photographs and scrapbooks, school work, correspondence, and audio-visual materials. Much of the collection has notes from MacKay explaining her relationship to individuals and organizations. Materials related to MacKay's work in the North Forks Women for Women Fund are in their own seperate collection.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: In 2019, approximately 3 record cartons were removed from the collection, icluding duplicates, blank stationary, sensitive information (third party student evaluations and financial records), and widely available Vassar materials (including scrapbooks and reunion books available at Vassar's archives).

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: To the extent that she owns copyright, Anne MacKay has retained copyright until her death in her works donated to Smith College. After her death, copyright in these works will transfer to Manuela Soares, and upon her death copyright passes to Smith College, with the exception of Wolf Girls at Vassar which passes to Vassar College. Copyright in other items in this collection may be held by their respective creators. For reproductions of materials that are governed by fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. For those few instances beyond fair use, or which may regard materials in the collection not created by MacKay, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights and obtaining approval from them. Researchers do not need anything further from Smith College Special Collections to move forward with their use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes photographs and materials pertaining to MacKay's childhood, personal correspondence, memorabilia and planning for MacKay's birthday celebrations, legal records concerning her father's death, backup disks from MacKay's personal computer, personal memorabilia, and recordings of performances by MacKay and friends. Additional personal correspondence and performances can be founding in the correspondence and theater series respectively.

did.unittitle: General attorney documentation, financials, and correspondene re. the estate of John J. MacKay
Gathering Committee and Women's Coffee House
John MacKay Home Movies video recording
"North Fork Women's Softball + Cruising Assn." T-shirt, undated
Finish of Perils & Singing in Davison and North (cassette)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In this series, Dalton materials and Vassar materials are seperate, and arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains materials on MacKay's education at the Dalton School and Vassar College, including schoolwork, scrapbooks, yearbooks, teacher's evaluations, records of theatrical productions, school publications, and correspondence with Dalton and Vassar classmates. Also included are materials about MacKay's work as an alum of both schools, including records regarding the Lesbian and Gay Alumni of Vassar College (LAGAVC) organization, correspondence with members of the LAGAVC, records of LGBT history at Vassar, and records and correspondence concerning class reunions.

Records of theatrical performances for Vassar reunions, such as "The Hallelujah Chorus Line", are included in "Education" rather than the "Theatre" series because they directly pertain to MacKay's experience at and involvement with Vassar College. Correspondence pertaining directly to Dalton or Vassar, including correspondence from former classmates, is included in "Education" rather than "Correspondence". This series contains only material pertaining to MacKay's own education; records of her time as a theatre teacher at the Dalton and Horace Mann Schools are included in "Theatre".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains MacKay's correspondence with friends, family, former students, and associates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes unpublished and notated drafts of MacKay's poetry; royalties agreements and bookstore orders re. "Wolf Girls at Vassar"; first and second editions of "Wolf Girls at Vassar" and "She Went A-Whaling"; unpublished manuscripts of MacKay's memoir "Just Lucky, I Guess"; unpublished science fiction manuscripts; literary journals containing MacKay's writing; collections of poetry; transcription of "Sandy Dee" oral history; correspondence, publicity, and newspaper clippings re. MacKay's writing; and recordings of a poetry reading and a talk re. "Wolf Girls at Vassar".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes equity agreements; songbooks, chord sheets, and sheet music; publicity, memorabilia, reviews, records, correspondence, pictures, and recordings re. productions directed by MacKay, including "Midsummer Revels" (1982), "Cruise" (1983), "Taking Liberties" (1984); material re. MacKay's time as a theatre teacher at the Dalton School and the Horace Mann School, including recordings, programs, and photographs; and recordings and records re. theatre performances MacKay supported but was not directly involved with.
School theatre included in this series relates to MacKay's professional life; her involvement in theatre as a student and alum are included in "Education".

did.unittitle: DVD "Taking Liberties", correspondence with Cassidy Holliger, Drama Dept., Mini Reunion
Clippings, "SPAT Oyster Gardener Turns 60 Eating Birthday Oysters"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains personal photographs taken by and of Mackay and her friends. Common subjects include gardens, cats, sailing, beaches, vacations, and gatherings of friends. Also included are early childhood and family photographs as well as photographs from Vassar reunions.
